item.title: Reduced Row Echelon Form
item.description: The blog explains how to find reduced row-echelon form of a matrix in python

item.title: Linear Classifier
item.description: The blog explains how to create a linear classifier from scratch using MSE loss and Sigmoid Function.

item.title: Co-Occurance Matrix
item.description: This blog contains an explanation and tutorial to create word embeddings via co-occurance matrix and svd

item.title: Reversing Huge Files
item.description: This blog contains an explanation and tutorial of how to reverse very large files in C

item.title: OWASP top10
item.description: This blog contains my walkthrough of the OWASP room in tryhackme while trying to learn more about cyber security. Check out the original room as well here.

item.title: Networks
item.description: Here is the stuff I read related to networks, different models and their working, OSI Model The OSI Model (Open Systems Interconnection Model) is a conceptual framework used to describe the functions of a networking system. It defines rules and requirements that support effortless data transfer between different products and software. In the OSI reference model, the communications between a computing system are split into seven different abstraction layers: Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Session, Presentation, and Application.

item.title: Connect Four, Part 1
item.description: This blog contains explanation of the paper by Victor Allis called ‘A Knowledge-based Approach of Connect-Four’

item.title: Connect Four, Part 2
item.description: This blog contains explanation of the paper by Victor Allis called ‘A Knowledge-based Approach of Connect-Four’ This is a 2 part series exploring the paper, and I would suggest going through ‘first part’ if you haven’t already.

item.title: Scotland Yard: Part 1
item.description:
This blog contains an explanation of the paper ‘The complexity of Scotland Yard’ by Merlijn Sevenster.

This is part 1 of a two part blog. Part 1 explains the game, and lays out the foundations required for formalisation of the game. It also lists out the various assumptions we are going to consider in the game.

The blog was originally published on ‘GameLab’ for our course project. The website also contains additional information about heuristics used in Scotland Yard, and similar analysis for other board games.

item.title: Scotland Yard: Part 2
item.description:
This blog contains an explanation of the paper ‘The complexity of Scotland Yard’ by Merlijn Sevenster.

This is part 2 of a two part blog. Part 1 explains the game, and lays out the foundations required for formalisation of the game. It also lists out the various assumptions we are going to consider in the game. Part 2 formalises the game and proves that it is of PSPACE complexity.

The blog was originally published on ‘GameLab’ for our course project. The website also contains additional information about heuristics used in Scotland Yard, and similar analysis for other board games.
